children.subject: I am guessing that could be true, but I don't trust the APR enough to say for sure. You're always able to come to CS drop-in advising on Wed 10-12PM & 1-4PM in 349 Soda or make an appointment in CalCentral. Degree checks are usually very fast, so come see us!

I understand that there may be situations in which the APR says you have not completed a requirement when you actually have. Are there also situations where the APR could say you have completed a requirement when you actually have not? I'm a senior graduating this semester, and while I'm quite confident I've completed the requirements (and the APR all looks right), I'm just a little paranoid and would like some sort of additional confirmation. Thanks!
Just checking -- this post does not apply to EECS students, right?
Hi There. We're not currently doing drop-in while we're fully remote, so please schedule an appointment in CalCentral with one of the advisors. Thanks!
Can we access drop in advising via zoom?

history.content:
We are happy to report that students may now use the Academic Progress Report (APR) for their CS major and minor requirements regardless of when you entered Berkeley. The APR is not perfect, so if you have questions about how it is counting your classes, email us at cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu or schedule an appointment in CalCentral.

If you opt to take Math 53, the APR will understand that it can waive 3 units of upper-div tech electives so there is no longer a need to make a special request for this. If the APR does not capture this and you want it to, send us an email.

Typical areas the APR may still struggle with are: tech electives, special topics & grad classes, study abroad classes, overlap classes with double majors, and/or if students had specific classes exceptionally approved for the major, e.g. transferred Math 1A from a non-CA community college. 

Students can continue to also use the APR for L&S & campus requirements.
history.subject: Update: OK to use the APR for CS requirements!

history.content:
We are happy to report that students may now use the Academic Progress Report (APR) for their CS major and minor requirements regardless of when you entered Berkeley. The APR is not perfect, so if you have questions about how it is counting your classes, email us at cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu or schedule an appointment in CalCentral.

If you opt to take Math 53, the APR will understand that it can waive 3 units of upper-div tech electives so there is no longer a need to make a special request for this. If the APR does not capture this and you want it to, send us an email.

Typical areas the APR may still struggle with are: tech electives, special topics & grad classes, study abroad classes, overlap classes with double majors, and/or if students had specific classes exceptionally approved for the major, e.g. transferred Math 1A from a non-CA community college. 

Students can continue to also use the APR for L&S & campus requirements. 

#pin
history.subject: Update: OK to use the APR for CS requirements!

history.content:
This is a friendly reminder that students should not be using the Academic Progress Report to check their CS requirements as it is not always accurate, particularly for tech electives (including Math 53 requests), special topics & grad classes, study abroad classes, and/or if students had specific classes exceptionally approved for the major. Students should instead meet with a CS advisor to verify their CS requirements are fulfilled. The APR can be used for L&S & campus requirements. 

Students can make an appointment with a CS advisor in CalCentral or come to drop-in advising on Wednesday, 10-12PM & 1-4PM in 349 Soda.

TL;DR: Come to CS advising for a degree check instead of using the APR.

#pin
history.subject: Do not use the APR for CS requirements; come to CS advising instead!
